Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Investigation of Immediate Post-fire Hydro-geochemical Coupling and Contaminant Flux in an Urban-fringe Watershed in Southern California
Award.AbstractNarration: The Station fire is currently noted as the largest fire in Los Angeles County history as well as the 10th largest fire in California history. The burned region is located immediately adjacent to dense urban areas on the east side of the Los Angeles basin. These urban-wildland regions, located in the San Gabriel Mountains, will now be impacted by increased flooding, debris and sediment-laden flows, and significant water quality issues. The San Gabriel Mountains are known to receive high loads of atmospheric pollutants (dry and wet)originating from the Los Angeles metropolitan region. Runoff from these mountains normally supplies significant runoff into downstream urban water ways, which is then directed to infiltration ponds or zones for aquifer recharge, or into conveyance channels that route water through dense urban areas to coastal bays. Postfire runoff in these urban-fringe watersheds may now contribute significant, and potentially toxic, chemical loads into downstream urban systems, affecting regional water supplies, biota and ecosystem function. Funds from this RAPID grant will allow an immediate and extensive investigation of storm-driven contaminant flux (including nutrients, metals, PAHs, sediments, and other ancillary parameters) in an urban fringe watershed affected by significant atmospheric deposition and that was burned in its entirety. Previously collected pre-fire data on the study watershed will allow a unique and comprehensive comparison to pre-burn behavior,advance knowledge on post-burn hydro-geochemical coupling and alterations in basin mass loading, and provide critical data to improve geochemical and hydrologic modeling in post-burn systems. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to better understand the mechanisms controlling alterations in the chemical and physical response of urban fringe watersheds after a catastrophic wildfire. Specifically, we propose to address the following science questions: 1) How does post-fire hydro-geochemical coupling (behavior) alter from pre-fire conditions? 2) How does storm variability influence post-fire runoff behavior and coupled contaminant flux? 3) What is the effect of burn on riparian nitrate soil storage and streamwater export? and 4) What is the impact of a catastrophic burn on seasonal pollutant loading to downstream urban systems?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The size and frequency of wildfires has been increasing across the western United States. The Station Fire, which occurred during the summer of 2009, is currently noted as the largest fire in Los Angeles County as well as the 10th largest fire in California history. The burned region is located immediately adjacent to dense urban areas on the east side of the Los Angeles basin. The forests in these regions are known to contain high levels of urban pollutants that originate from the large metropolitan center. Runoff from these mountains also supplies significant runoff into downstream urban water ways, which is then directed to infiltration ponds for groundwater recharge, or into storm channels that route water through dense urban areas to the Pacific Ocean. Funds from this NSF RAPID grant were used to undertake investigations of post-fire water quality in a watershed on the eastern edge of Los Angeles (the Arroyo Seco) that was burned in its entirety during the Station Fire. Previously collected water quality on the same watershed allowed us to undertake a unique comparison to pre-burn data. The objectives of the study were to better understand the impacts of wildfire on stream chemistry in polluted, urban-fringe landscapes in order to provide guidance for watershed management in burned watersheds.

Our investigations showed that the Station Fire resulted in significantly higher storm flows as well as higher sediment and chemical concentrations in the Arroyo Seco the first year after the fire.  Our pre-fire data showed that only large storms were able to mobilize contaminants in the basin. However, after the wildfire, even small storms resulted in chemical concentrations that exceeded water quality standards.  The greatest changes were observed in trace metals, where concentrations increased significantly following the Station Fire.  Urban pollutants, such as Cadmium and Lead, exhibited concentrations in the range of those observed in channels draining highways, industrial areas, and mining operations.  These urban pollutants are primarily being delivered through sediment transport (attached to eroded soil particles) during storm events. The timing of chemical delivery also changed after the fire, which contributed to significant increases in mean chemical concentrations and total contaminant delivery.

Results from this study have significant implications for post-fire storm water management. These extensively burned watersheds are contributing significant and highly toxic chemical loads into downstream urban systems, affecting regional water supplies, biota and ecosystem function. Water quality treatment is typically not undertaken for storm runoff from burned watersheds. Our results show that new management strategies and treatment methods are needed for post-fire systems.  The use of flood control structures that retain sediment are likely the most effective (and available) means to mitigate detrimental impacts to downstream water quality. However, we advocate that in the future, the chemistry of captured sediment must be considered prior to disposal, especially in watersheds located near large urban centers.
